title: Coldwell Banker vs Keller Williams: Which is Best for Realtors?
excerpt: This article will provide a comprehensive comparison between Coldwell Banker vs Keller Williams to help you determine which brokerage better aligns with your professional goals.…
content:
This article will provide a comprehensive comparison between Coldwell Banker vs Keller Williams to help you determine which brokerage better aligns with your professional goals. Choosing the right brokerage is a critical decision for any real estate agent, as it significantly impacts their career trajectory and financial success.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Coldwell Banker vs Keller Williams
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

The commission splits and associated fees are crucial factors to consider when selecting a brokerage. Keller Williams offers flexible splits ranging from 70/30 to 100/0, with a 6% franchise/royalty fee until the cap is reached. In contrast, Coldwell Banker provides splits starting at 55/45 and going up to 90/10, with a franchise/royalty fee ranging from 5% to 6.5%.

Monthly fees also differ significantly. Keller Williams’ fees vary by office, adding a layer of complexity to the cost structure. Coldwell Banker’s fees are more predictable, ranging from $150 to $179 per month, and include the royalty fee. Additionally, while Keller Williams does not charge transaction fees, Coldwell Banker includes transaction fees within their royalty fees. These differences make each brokerage unique, potentially impacting an agent’s net income and financial planning.

Income Opportunities

The potential for additional income streams can significantly enhance an agent’s financial stability and growth. Keller Williams stands out by offering revenue share programs that provide a retirement and willable income path. These additional income streams can offer substantial long-term financial benefits and security. Conversely, Coldwell Banker does not offer such supplementary income opportunities, limiting agents primarily to their commission-based earnings.

Training and Support

Effective training and support are vital for both new and experienced agents. Keller Williams excels in this area, providing extensive training opportunities, though specific details on the extent of their offerings are not standardized across all offices. Agents at Keller Williams also benefit from various support structures, although 24/7 support is not available. In contrast, Coldwell Banker provides training that varies by office and lacks the extensive and consistent support system available at Keller Williams. This difference can be crucial for agents who require ongoing assistance and professional development.

Technology and Resources

In the modern real estate landscape, leveraging technology effectively is essential. Keller Williams is known for its robust technology platforms, offering tools that enhance productivity and client engagement. On the other hand, Coldwell Banker, while incorporating some technological tools, still focuses heavily on traditional, physical office spaces. This might appeal to agents who prefer a more conventional working environment but may not offer the same level of flexibility and innovation as Keller Williams.

Agent Satisfaction

Agent satisfaction is a key indicator of a brokerage’s effectiveness and overall agent happiness. Both Keller Williams and Coldwell Banker have high Glassdoor ratings of 4.3 stars, indicating strong agent approval and satisfaction. However, the volume of reviews differs significantly, with Keller Williams having 7.9K reviews compared to Coldwell Banker’s 2.6K reviews. The differences in agent satisfaction can often be attributed to the varying levels of support, training, and income opportunities provided by each brokerage.

Final Thoughts on Coldwell Banker vs Keller Williams

In comparing Coldwell Banker and Keller Williams, it’s evident that Keller Williams offers more favorable commission splits, extensive training, and additional income opportunities, making it a compelling choice for both new and experienced agents. The innovative technology and comprehensive support further enhance Keller Williams’ appeal. Coldwell Banker, while offering a traditional structure with some technological integration, has higher fees and fewer income paths, which may limit its appeal to agents seeking comprehensive support and modern business solutions.

For a more detailed comparison and to find the best brokerage for your needs, check out our brokerage comparison tool.

When making your decision, consider your specific needs and career objectives. Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages carefully to choose the brokerage that best fits your professional aspirations. Whether you prioritize comprehensive support and training or seek a brokerage with a more conventional setup, your decision should align with your long-term career goals and preferences.

title: Top 17 Brokerage Interview Questions to Ask Before Choosing
excerpt: Need to choose a brokerage to hang your real estate license? It’s a critical choice that can easily shape your entire career. Pick the wrong…
content:
Need to choose a brokerage to hang your real estate license? It’s a critical choice that can easily shape your entire career. Pick the wrong brokerage and you could be among the 87% of new agents who give up their real estate dreams within five years.

So, how do you dodge that failure rate? You’ll need to ask the right questions when you interview with local real estate offices or conduct online research regarding cloud-based models. But what are the right questions? It’s not easy to know, especially is you’re a new agent.

But don’t sweat it! This article lays out exactly which brokerage interview questions you need to get answered. Stick with us to make your brokerage choice a stepping stone to success, not just another fail statistic. Here’s your handy dandy index:

Starting Your Brokerage Search

Your Career Advantage
Evaluating Responses
Choosing the Right Brokerage Checklist

Making Your Choice
Next Steps
It’s a Wrap
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty
Frequently Asked Questions

Starting Your Brokerage Search

Alright, you’ve snagged your real estate license. What’s the next move? Choosing the right brokerage can be a game-changer. Plus, it’s a decision that’s more complex than ever due to all the real estate industry disrupters.

There’s a lot to unpack here. Let’s kick things off by understanding the different brokerage models currently making waves.

Traditional brokerage models

Think classic franchise setup with brick-and-mortar offices where broker-owners manage recruitment. It’s the old-school way that is currently still very much in play.

Discount traditional brokerage models

Similar in vibe to traditional, but with a twist. That twist? Lower costs for clients and, yep, lower earnings for agents.

Hybrid brokerage models

These guys mix it up with physical offices and tech boosts. This model aims to lower costs through tech without ditching the office vibe completely.

Cloud-based brokerage models

The new kids on the block! These models ditch physical offices completely, cutting down middlemen and overhead. They’re all about using tech to streamline operations and empower agents like you to lead the way in recruitment.

Each model has its perks, depending on what you’re looking for. The brokerage model you choose will shape your career path. Let’s make sure it’s a shape you like!

Your Career Advantage

Before we get into the brokerage interview questions, there’s something else you should know. That is, interviewing for a real estate agent position is not like interviewing for most other jobs.

Why? Because you’re a revenue generator for any brokerage through your hard-earned commissions and the fees you pay to your brokerage. Additionally, most of your business expenses come out of your pocket, not your brokerages. So, unlike other jobs, real estate brokerages incur minimal costs when they bring you on board.

But here’s the twist: if you’re a new agent, the time invested in training you and meeting your day-to-day questions is huge. If a brokerage isn’t hiring, or if they pass on offering you a position, it’s likely due to a lack of structured training or adequate staff to support your growth.

This happens more commonly in franchise brokerages or smaller outfits. That’s because even if t the responsibility for answering your day-to-day questions often falls on just one person – the broker-owner of the franchise office. Hiring you depends on that broker’s time availability.

On the flip side, this time for new agents problem is better with some cloud-based brokerages. These modern setups often have dedicated staff ready to support new agents.

Additionally, at a cloud-based brokerage, the hiring process can be remarkably streamlined. Sometimes you can join the brokerage through just a simple online application, bypassing traditional interviews altogether.

This makes it easier and faster to kickstart your real estate career. But, before you hit the join button, be sure to get the brokerage interview questions answered.

Evaluating Responses

Last, before we get to the brokerage interview questions, let’s talk about how to really listen to the answers you’ll get. It’s not just the content of the answers that matters, but also how they’re delivered.

Genuine enthusiasm and openness in their responses can reveal a lot about the brokerage’s stability and their commitment to supporting your career. On the other hand, evasiveness or lack of detail can be significant red flags, signaling that the brokerage might not be the best fit for your ambitions.

So listen carefully – it’s about finding a supportive environment where you can thrive, not just a place to work.

Choosing the Right Brokerage Checklist

Alright, let’s get to those brokerage interview questions. Whether you’re sitting down face-to-face in a traditional brokerage office or filling out forms online for a cloud-based firm, you’ll want these answers.

Commission Splits

Commission splits vary widely across brokerages and they are likely to be the number one anchor to your earnings happiness. If you don’t understand all the ins and outs of commissions, check out our blog article “Best Real Estate Companies to Work For – By Commission Splits” on SmartAgentAlliance.com.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What commission split is offered by the brokerage?
  2. Does the commission split improve after reaching certain milestones?
  3. What specific sales targets or other requirements must I meet to qualify for a better split?

Fees

Time for the nitty-gritty of brokerage fees, which can significantly impact your take-home pay.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What are all the fees I’ll need to pay? Find out every fee you’ll encounter, including royalty fees, transaction fees, desk fees, and Errors & Omissions Insurance and more.
  2. When are these fees due? Are they payable upfront or are they deducted as you close each deal? Are the fees due monthly or annually?
  3. Are there any fee caps? For example, there might be a per-deal fee that ceases (“caps”) once you’ve done a certain number of deals.

Training Programs

The best brokerages provide robust new agent training and ongoing training for seasoned agents too.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What types of training are available, and who conducts it? You want these to be led by actively producing successful agents.
  2. Is the training live, on-demand, or both? You need to know how flexible the training options are to suit your changing needs.
  3. What specific areas do your training programs cover? You’re looking for a variety of training from mindset and task management to modern lead generation (like social media training) and contract handling.
  4. Are there any fees associated with training? Some brokerage talk about their training, but then you find out it’s done by a third party that charges thousands of dollars.

Technology

Technology in real estate is a necessity.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What specific technology tools does the brokerage offer? Do they provide a customer relationship management (CRM) tool, individual IDX websites, tools for managing deal documents or promoting listings?
  2. Are these tools included in my brokerage fees, or are there additional costs?
  3. Can I access a demonstration of these technology tools before deciding?
  4. How often does the brokerage unleash new technology or update it? If it’s not at least annually, their tech may already be outdated.

Day-to-Day Support

Quality support ensures you’re never alone when challenges arise, whether it’s handling transaction details, navigating client negotiations, or managing paperwork.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What type of support is available to agents and how do I access it? Determine if support is available by phone, chat, email or just FAQs online.
  2. Is support available 24/7 and who provides it? You’ll want to gauge whether support is quality, like a broker, or just random staff. And, you’ll want to know if they are available for urgent situations.
  3. How many staff members are dedicated to agent support, and what is their response time? Get an idea now if you’ll have to wait long for answers.
  4. Is there a dedicated mentor or point of contact for new agents? If you’re a new agent, you’ll want this, big time!

Lead Generation

Lead generation is how you fill your pipeline of potential clients. It’s the heart of your success.

and potential sales opportunities. A supportive brokerage can significantly enhance your ability to generate leads by providing both resources for independent lead generation and direct referrals. Understanding the types of lead generation support offered by a brokerage can help you choose a firm that aligns with your business style and goals.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. Does the brokerage provide leads or referrals? If so, how many can I expect over what period? Are the leads fresh and qualified? Caution…agents often complain they were told they’d get leads but the reality is that the leads ended up being nonexistent, super rare, or of very low quality.
  2. What tools and resources does the brokerage offer for generating my own leads? We aren’t talking about training here. You want to know if they provide lead generation tools like the ability to quickly and inexpensively start an ad campaign or farm a neighborhood.
  3. Are there any fees associated with lead generation services? For example, sometimes agents give up a good chunk of their earned commission in exchange for the lead.

Marketing Support

Effective marketing is essential for real estate success.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What type of marketing support does the brokerage provide? Look for support that covers a broad range of marketing strategies, including digital marketing, direct mail, and professional listing presentations.
  2. Does the brokerage offer easily customizable flyers, letterhead, social media posts, listing packages, farming packages, etc.? High-quality visuals are necessary. You need to know how difficult and costly it will be for you to create them.
  3. How does the brokerage support newer or less traditional marketing efforts like email campaigns and social media marketing? Determine if they offer any innovative marketing methods that are quick, easy, and inexpensive to give you a competitive edge.

Stock Rewards

Stock rewards can be a significant incentive when choosing a brokerage with listed stock.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. Does the brokerage offer stock rewards or can agents buy stock at a discount?
  2. How do I earn stock awards and when do those shares vest? You’ll want to know how much extra income you can expect and when that income becomes all yours.

Agent Perks

Agent perks can significantly enhance job satisfaction and financial well-being.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What kind of agent perks does the brokerage offer? Identify perks such as healthcare benefits, retirement plans, or passive income opportunities.
  2. Can I earn recruiting income and is it willable or available after retirement? If yes, inquire about how it’s earned and how much you can earn.

Office Space

Because most real estate client business happens in homes, the necessity of office space depends greatly on how you prefer to work.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What types of office spaces are available? For traditional brokerages, determine if you get a private office or cubicle. For cloud-based brokerages, find out if they offer office arrangements like Regus.
  2. Are there additional fees for different types of office spaces? Yep, sometimes there are additional charges.

Innovation

Because the real estate industry is quickly evolving and because there’s more brokerage competition than ever before, you need a brokerage that constantly innovates to meet that challenge.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. How often does the brokerage add something innovative for agents or their clients? This needs to be several times a year!
  2. What new tools and resources were introduced in the last year? Here’s how you evaluate the quality of the tools and resources.

New Agent Mentorship

Mentorship is a game-changer for new real estate agents, accelerating their path to successful deal closures.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. Does the brokerage offer structured mentorship programs for new agents? This will indicate if their mentorship program is well planned out.
  2. Who are the mentors and what are their credentials? This will give you an idea of the mentorship quality.
  3. How much does mentorship cost? There may be a fee or an extra deal split for the help.

Networking Opportunities

Networking with other agents opens up potential for referrals and business partnerships.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What types of networking opportunities does the brokerage provide? Note if they are local, national, or global opportunities.
  2. Are there local meetups, regional events, and/or national conferences? The more the better for you!
  3. Do the networking opportunities offer new skills training or meet influential industry professionals? This will tell you the baseline advantage of attending any events.

Culture and Values

A brokerage’s culture will define your work environment and job satisfaction.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. How would you describe the brokerage’s culture? Try to determine if the environment is collaborative, competitive, or somewhere in between.
  2. Can I speak with some current agents about their experiences here? Talking to current agents gives you a real-world perspective on the day-to-day culture and how the brokerage supports its team.
  3. For cloud-based brokerages, what platforms are in place for agent interaction and community building? Knowing how you’ll communicate and collaborate with peers in a virtual environment is essential for cloud-based setups.

Brokerage Branding

Recognizable brokerage awards or a strong market presence can enhance your agent credibility making it easier to get clients. However, keep in mind that in real estate, you are really the brand.  Still, brokerage branding can help.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. What distinguishes this brokerage from others?
  2. Has the brokerage received any notable awards or recognitions?

Client Perks

Offering unique client perks can set a brokerage apart and provide significant value to the clients you’ll serve. These perks can be the deciding factor for clients choosing to work with you.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. Are renovation, cleaning, or staging services offered where payment is deferred until closing?
  2. Does the brokerage provide cash offers for clients not wanting to list?
  3. Does the brokerage have exclusive organized off-market property listings?
  4. Is there global marketing for high-end properties? Find out if those have an additional fee for you to provide.
  5. Are there any other client perks? Cover all bases with that final question.

Brokerage Model Sustainability

The real estate industry is going through significant growing pains. With the rise of efficient cloud-based models and new NAR rules potentially impacting commission rates, traditional brokerages are facing heavy challenges.

However, some cloud-based models are also struggling. That’s because some of these new kids on the block haven’t yet configured agent commissions, fees, and support that will make them profitable and sustainable.

You’ll want to ensure that the brokerage you choose is not only surviving but thriving. If your brokerage is not thriving, you’re likely to see agent commissions, fees, and support worsen. Plus, innovation will not keep pace with successful brokerages.

Key Questions to Ask:

  1. Was your brokerage profitable after all expenses last year? How about the year before that?
  2. If not, what strategies are in place to achieve future profitability?
  3. Has your brokerage raised fees or lowered agent commission in the last 5 years?
  4. If so, what were those changes?

Understanding a brokerage’s financial health will give you insight into whether the brokerage will stand the test of time.

Making Your Choice

Now, the tough part—making the decision. Don’t rush it. Reflect on how each brokerage’s offerings align with what matters most to you personally and professionally.

Is it the training, the support, the technology, the commission structure, the likely sustainability of the model, or a combination of things? Prioritizing these factors will help you make an informed choice that best supports your career goals in real estate.

Next Steps

Once you’ve made your choice, communicate it with clarity and confidence. If you’re on board, show your eagerness to start. If not, decline politely—thank them for the opportunity.

Remember, real estate is a tightly knit industry, and maintaining positive relationships is crucial, regardless of your decision. Keep those bridges intact for future opportunities.

It’s a Wrap

Picking the right brokerage is a big move. Think of it as finding a new home for your career. You want it to fit just right. You’ve got the tools and know-how to make a smart choice. Trust yourself.

Ready to get to it? Go nail that interview. Ask the tough questions because now you know what matters. Remember, it’s about finding a place where you can grow, learn, and thrive. Your future’s bright. Make this count. And hey, we’re here cheering you on every step of the way.

Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Not only will you be joining the ONLY profitable public brokerage in the past 5 years that agents rank as the best brokerage to work for, but you’ll also benefit from double the free resources (two teams in your upline) designed to help you succeed quickly and efficiently at eXp.

With the Wolf Pack, you’ll enjoy exclusive access to the Wolf Pack weekly webinars, the Social Agent Academy for social media training, the Wolf Pack Hub for easy onboarding, Investor Army for investing and flipping houses training.

With Smart Agent Alliance you’ll enjoy personalized day-to-day concierge care plus assets like customizable agent presentations, business automation, production checklists, customizable social media posts, and so much more.

Don’t miss out on this amazing opportunity to maximize your earnings and build a thriving real estate business. Join eXp Realty today and experience unparalleled support from both the Wolf Pack and Smart Agent Alliance.

Not quite convinced? No problem! Contact us to set up a meeting, request a personal link to a live webinar, and/or get all your questions answered via email, phone call, or video call. We’re here to help you succeed!

For more information, check out our eXp Realty overview, learn about our team benefits, and visit our Join Smart Agent Alliance page. Partner with us today and take your real estate career to the next level!

Frequently Asked Questions

What are the different real estate brokerage models?

Traditional brokerage models are the classic franchise setup with brick-and-mortar offices where broker-owners manage recruitment. Discount traditional brokerage models are those that discount their services and what agents earn. Hybrid brokerage models mix it up with physical offices and tech boosts to lower costs. Cloud-based brokerage models ditch physical offices completely, cutting down middlemen and overhead. They’re all about using tech to streamline operations.

How is interviewing as a real estate agent different than other professions?

It’s different because agents generate revenue for the brokerage through commissions while paying fees and most business expenses themselves, minimizing costs for the brokerage. However, the time investment in training new agents and addressing daily inquiries is substantial. Cloud-based brokerages better accommodate new agents with dedicated support staff and streamlined hiring processes, sometimes allowing agents to join through a simple online application, eliminating traditional interviews.

What real estate brokerage interview questions should I ask?

Ask about commission splits, fees, training, technology, lead generation, marketing support, stock rewards, mentorship, networking opportunities, company culture, and agent perks like: healthcare, retirement plans, and recruiting bonuses. Also ask how much the company innovates, how profitable is the company after expenses, and are their client perks like global advertising or renovations where the associated costs are zero until closing.

title: Best Online Real Estate Schools in California
excerpt: Choosing one of the best online real estate schools in California is crucial for your career, and it's important to thoroughly research your options and…
content:
Choosing one of the best online real estate schools in California is crucial for your career, and it’s important to thoroughly research your options and understand what each course offers. While there are countless real estate schools available, only a select few stand out for their exceptional education and comprehensive support in preparing you to obtain your real estate license.

At Smart Agent Alliance, we are committed to guiding new agents in launching successful careers. That’s why we’ve curated a list of the leading online real estate schools in California. Our detailed analysis covers the offerings of each school, their course delivery methods, and a balanced view of the advantages and disadvantages of studying with each one.

  1. AceableAgent – Best Overall
  2. The CE Shop – Runner Up
  3. Allied Real Estate Schools – Most Comprehensive
  4. RealEstateU – Best Cheap Option
  5. 360 Training – Cheap, but not recommended

AceableAgent – Best Overall

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A+
Top Feature: Ability to study on the go with the mobile app

Why We Chose It

AceableAgent has quickly become a favorite among students due to its modern approach and flexibility. It is exclusively focused on real estate education, offering courses for every step of a real estate career, from pre-licensing to continuing education and career advancement. The courses are state-approved and designed to be accessible from any device, providing students with the flexibility to study anywhere.

Overview

AceableAgent offers three pre-licensing packages, all of which include the required coursework. The courses are fully online and accessible via desktop, laptop, tablet, or smartphone. This accessibility is one of AceableAgent’s standout features, allowing students to study on the go. Courses are developed by experienced professionals and are accredited by ARELLO. Additionally, AceableAgent is known for its interactive coursework, which helps students grasp and retain information effectively.

Why AceableAgent is Great for Pre-Licensing

AceableAgent’s pre-licensing courses are available in multiple states, ensuring they meet state-specific requirements. The courses include engaging video lectures, interactive content, and practice exams to help students prepare effectively for their licensing exams. AceableAgent offers a satisfaction guarantee and provides career resources to help new agents start their careers successfully.

California Pricing

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $199

Basic Package Features: 24/7 email support from course experts; self-paced online learning on all devices with synced progress; 900 unique exam practice questions; mini-course on finding the right sponsoring broker.

Upgrade Packages: Yes, the upgraded packages include features like a 24/7 virtual instructor, 3 months of PrepAgent state exam prep, private tutoring, weekly webinars, and access to extensive study materials.

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $59

Basic Package Features: Thousands of practice questions; 100% money-back guarantee; 75+ real estate exam prep videos; online interactive flashcards; 100+ page exam prep ebook; hours of audio lessons; interactive vocabulary worksheet; 100s of hours of recorded webinars; live online webinars.

Upgrade Packages: Yes, the upgraded packages offer access to PrepAgent for 1 or 2 months, compared to just 1 week with the basic plan.

Key Features

  • Flexible Learning Options: Enjoy self-paced courses that fit your schedule.
  • Extended Course Access: Access course materials for up to six months from your enrollment date.
  • Risk-Free Enrollment: Benefit from a 30-day money-back guarantee if you’re not satisfied.
  • Exam Success Guarantee: Pass the licensing exam within three tries or receive a full course refund.
  • Comprehensive Exam Preparation: Gain access to a variety of study tools including prep videos, 75 audio lessons, digital flashcards, over 1600 practice questions, a 100-page exam prep ebook, weekly live webinars, live Q&A sessions with instructors, and the option for personalized 1-on-1 tutoring.
  • Dedicated Support: Instructor assistance is available seven days a week via email, and customer service can be reached by email and phone from Monday to Friday.
  • Mobile-Friendly Platform: Study anytime, anywhere with a course platform that is fully optimized for mobile devices.
  • Interactive Learning Tools: Engage with interactive content designed to enhance your learning experience and retention.
  • Career Resources: Access additional career support services to help you transition from student to professional agent successfully.

Pros and Cons

Pros: Modern interface, excellent mobile app, interactive content, satisfaction guarantee, comprehensive exam prep.

Cons: Customer service can sometimes be slow to respond.

The CE Shop – Runner Up

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Course is easy to follow, high pass rates among students

Why We Chose It

The CE Shop offers a variety of real estate education options with an interactive and inquiry-based approach in their studying methods. While their focus is mainly on continuing education, they also provide excellent pre-licensing courses, exam prep, and post-licensing education. Their courses are accredited by ARELLO and have received numerous awards for their educational programs.

Overview

The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses can be taken in 34 states, through four different course packages: Courses Only, Standard Package, Value Package, and Premium Package. Every package comes with business ebooks, career resources, downloadable resources, real estate glossary, digital flashcards, study schedules, and access to instructor-led webinars. Students have praised the course content for being easy to follow and highly informative, which has led to high pass rates.

Why The CE Shop is Great for Pre-Licensing

The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses emphasize real-world applications with scenario-based learning. This approach helps students apply their knowledge to practical situations they will face in their real estate careers. Additionally, The CE Shop provides an exam prep edge program that offers additional practice tests and study aids to ensure students are well-prepared for their licensing exams.

California Pricing

Pre-Licensing

Price Starts at: $111.20

Basic Package Features: Expert-written business eBooks, career resources, downloadable materials, digital flashcards, a real estate glossary, a study schedule, and 135 hours of CA pre-licensing preparation.

Upgrade Packages: The Premium Package includes everything in the Basic Package, plus exam prep ($135 value), a pass guarantee, Kickstarter professional development ($99 value), the Real Estate Basics and Beyond eTextbook ($35 value), and a 45-hour first renewal package ($79 value).

Exam Prep

Price Starts at: $101.25

Basic Package Features: Offers content based on the California DRE Instructions to License Applicants, ensuring comprehensive coverage of every exam topic. It features individual lessons for efficient studying, real-time dashboards to gauge exam readiness, and 7-day support via call, chat, or email.

Continuing Education

Price Starts at: $79

Basic Package Features: This 45-hour CE package includes 17 mandatory hours (ethics, agency, fair housing, trust fund handling, risk management, implicit bias), 19 consumer protection hours (real estate finance, commercial real estate, environmental awareness, sexual harassment and discrimination, assistance animals and fair housing), and 9 consumer service hours (marketing, business planning, investor strategies).

Key Features

  • Learning Format: Flexible, self-paced online courses.
  • Access Duration: Six months from the start date.
  • Money-Back Guarantee: Full refund within 30 days if less than 50% of the course is completed.
  • Pass Assurance: Exam cost reimbursed if you don’t pass on the first attempt.
  • Exam Preparation: Targeted review sessions, custom study plans, unlimited practice tests, and live webinars.
  • Support Services: Available daily via email, phone, or chat.
  • Extra Resources: Includes digital flashcards, a real estate glossary, a study schedule, business courses, and state-specific content.

Pros and Cons

Pros: Easy-to-follow content, high pass rates, comprehensive support, frequent promotions.

Cons: Some students find the interface less modern than competitors.

Allied Real Estate Schools – Most Comprehensive

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Affordable and comprehensive study materials

Why We Chose It

Allied Real Estate Schools is known for its affordability and thorough course materials. It provides excellent support to students preparing for their exams and offers a range of courses that cater to different learning needs. Allied’s courses are designed to be clear and easy to understand, making them a great choice for budget-conscious students.

Overview

Allied Real Estate Schools offers various online courses with comprehensive study materials. The courses are designed to prepare students effectively for their licensing exams, with detailed support and resources. The pricing is competitive, making it an accessible option for many students.

Why Allied Real Estate Schools is Great for Pre-Licensing

title: How to Get a Real Estate License in California
excerpt: Getting your California real estate license might seem daunting, but with the right guidance, it’s a straightforward process. This comprehensive guide on how to obtain…
content:
Getting your California real estate license might seem daunting, but with the right guidance, it’s a straightforward process. This comprehensive guide on how to obtain a California real estate license will walk you through each step, ensuring you’re well-prepared to start your real estate career in California. Let’s get started on your journey to becoming a licensed real estate agent.

  1. Understand the Basic Requirements
  2. Step 1: Take a Real Estate Pre-Licensing Course
  3. Step 2: Submit Your California Real Estate License Application
  4. Step 3: Pass the California Real Estate Exam
  5. Step 4: Complete the Fingerprinting Requirement
  6. Step 5: Submit the Salesperson License Application
  7. Step 6: Find a Real Estate Broker to Sponsor You
  8. Find a Sponsoring Broker

Understand the Basic Requirements

Before diving into the specifics, it’s essential to understand the basic requirements for a California real estate license. These are the fundamental criteria you must meet:

Age Requirement

You must be at least 18 years old to apply for a real estate license in California. This age requirement ensures that applicants have reached a level of maturity and legal responsibility necessary for the profession.

Residency and Identification

While you don’t need to be a California resident to obtain a license, you must have a Social Security number or an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). This identification is crucial for background checks and to ensure compliance with state regulations. Out-of-state applicants for a California real estate license must meet the same criteria as California residents.

Honesty and Integrity

You must be honest and truthful in all your dealings. The California Department of Real Estate (DRE) will conduct a thorough background check, and any conviction of a crime may result in the denial of your license. Being upfront about any past legal issues and demonstrating rehabilitation can positively impact your application.

Step 1: Take a Real Estate Pre-Licensing Course

In California, you need to complete 135 hours of real estate pre-licensing education. This course covers essential topics like real estate principles, practices, and legal aspects.

“Any real estate practice course submitted for purposes of qualifying to take a real estate license exam, must include components on implicit bias and fair housing. Additionally, the fair housing component must include an interactive participatory component where the applicant role plays as both the consumer and the real estate professional.” -DRE

Course Breakdown

Real Estate Principles (45 hours)

This course covers the fundamentals of real estate, including property ownership, land use controls, and regulations. Understanding these principles is essential for anyone entering the real estate field.

Real Estate Practice (45 hours)

Real Estate Practice focuses on the practical aspects of working as a real estate agent. Topics include listing agreements, sales processes, and client relationships. This course prepares you for the day-to-day activities you will encounter in your real estate career.

Elective Course (45 hours)

The elective course allows you to specialize in an area of interest, such as Real Estate Finance, Real Estate Appraisal, or Property Management. Choosing an elective that aligns with your career goals can provide a competitive edge.

Choosing the Right School

Selecting the right California real estate school is crucial. Look for accredited schools that offer flexibility, especially if you have a busy schedule. Online real estate courses in California can provide the convenience of studying at your own pace.

Research Schools: Start by researching various California real estate schools and reading reviews from past students. Look for schools with high pass rates for the real estate exam and positive feedback on their teaching methods.

Consider Online vs. In-Person: Decide whether you prefer online or in-person real estate classes in California. Online courses offer flexibility and convenience, allowing you to study at your own pace. In-person classes provide direct interaction with instructors and peers, which can enhance your learning experience.

Evaluate Course Materials: Evaluate the course materials and support services provided by the school. High-quality textbooks, interactive lessons, and access to instructors for questions can significantly impact your success. Some schools also offer additional resources like exam prep courses and study groups.

Study Tips

  • Create a daily study schedule that covers all exam topics, ensuring regular review sessions. (Asana provides a great FREE task manager)
  • Utilize flashcards for key terms and concepts to enhance memorization. (These Quizlet Flashcards may be helpful)
  • Regularly take practice tests to gauge your understanding and get familiar with the exam format. (Free California Real Estate Practice Exam)

Step 2: Submit Your California Real Estate License Application

After completing your coursework, submit your license application to the DRE:

  1. Complete the Application Form: Fill out the RE 435 form available on the DRE website. (Click here to access the form)
  2. Gather Required Documents: Include proof of completed pre-licensing education and identification documents.
  3. Schedule Fingerprinting: Use the Live Scan service to complete your background check.
  4. Submit Your Application: Mail or submit your application online through the DRE’s eLicensing system.

Processing Time: The DRE will take several weeks to process your application. During this time, they will review your transcripts and verify that you meet all the requirements. Make sure to double-check your application for completeness to avoid any delays.

Track Your Application: You can track the status of your application online through the DRE’s website. Regularly checking the status can help you stay informed about any issues or additional requirements.

Step 3: Pass the California Real Estate Exam

The exam is a 3-hour test with 150 multiple-choice questions. You need to score at least 70% to pass. Each attempt requires a new application and a fee of $60.

Exam Topics

Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations (approximately 15%)

  • Classes of Property
  • Property Characteristics
  • Encumbrances
  • Types of Ownership
  • Descriptions of Property
  • Government Rights in Land
  • Public Controls
  • Environmental Hazards and Regulations
  • Private Controls
  • Water Rights
  • Special Categories of Land

Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties (approximately 17%)

  • Law, Definition and Nature of Agency Relationships, Types of Agencies, and Agents
  • Creation of Agency and Agency Agreements
  • Responsibilities of Agent to Seller/Buyer as Principal
  • Disclosure of Agency
  • Disclosure of Acting as Principal or Other Interest
  • Termination of Agency
  • Commission and Fees
  • Responsibilities of Agent to Non-Client Third Parties

Property Valuation and Financial Analysis (approximately 14%)

  • Value
  • Methods of Estimating Value
  • Financial Analysis

Financing (approximately 9%)

  • General Concepts
  • Types of Loans
  • Sources of Financing
  • Government Programs
  • Mortgages/Deeds of Trust/Notes
  • Financing/Credit Laws
  • Loan Brokerage
  • Types of Loan Originators

Transfer of Property (approximately 8%)

  • Title Insurance
  • Deeds
  • Escrow
  • Tax Aspects
  • Special Processes
  • Transfer through Court Supervision
  • Types of Vesting

Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures (approximately 25%)

  • Trust Account Management
  • Fair Housing Laws
  • Truth in Advertising
  • Record Keeping Requirements
  • Agency Supervision
  • Permitted Activities of Unlicensed Sales Assistants
  • DRE Jurisdiction and Disciplinary Actions
  • Licensing, and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
  • California Real Estate Recovery Fund
  • General Ethics
  • Technology
  • Property Management
  • Commercial/Industrial/Income Properties
  • Specialty Areas
  • Transfer Disclosure Statement
  • Natural Hazard Disclosure Statements
  • Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
  • Need for Inspection and Obtaining/Verifying Information
  • Reports
  • Servicing Diverse Populations

Contracts (approximately 12%)

  • General
  • Listing Agreements
  • Buyer Broker Agreements
  • Offers/Purchase Contracts
  • Agreements
  • Promissory Notes/Securities
  • Purchase/Lease Options
  • Advanced Fee

Exam Preparation Tips

Review Course Materials: Go over the textbooks and notes from your pre-license courses. Revisiting these materials can reinforce your understanding of key concepts. Focus on areas where you feel less confident to ensure a well-rounded preparation.

Take Practice Exams: Take as many practice exams as possible. This helps you get familiar with the exam format and identify areas where you need more study. (Free California Real Estate Practice Exam)

Join Study Groups: Join or form study groups. Discussing topics with peers can enhance understanding and retention. Study groups provide a platform to share knowledge, ask questions, and support each other.

Consider Exam Prep Courses: Consider enrolling in an exam prep course for additional support and structured study. These courses often include practice exams, study guides, and expert instruction.

Tips for Exam Day

  • Arrive Early: Ensure you arrive at the exam center early to avoid any last-minute stress. Check the location and travel time in advance.
  • Bring Valid ID: You’ll need a valid photo ID to enter the exam. Make sure your ID is current and matches the name on your application.
  • Stay Calm: Read each question carefully and manage your time wisely. Staying calm and composed can help you think clearly and avoid mistakes.
  • Follow Instructions: Follow all instructions given by the exam proctors. If you have any questions or issues, ask the proctors for assistance.

Step 4: Complete the Fingerprinting Requirement

After passing the exam, you must complete a fingerprinting requirement for a background check. This is a mandatory step to ensure you meet the honesty and integrity standards set by the DRE.

Live Scan Process

Find a Provider: Use a Live Scan service provider approved by the California Department of Justice. Live Scan is an electronic fingerprinting process that is fast and secure. Locate a service provider near you and schedule an appointment. (You can get this done at UPS for $65)

Submit Required Forms: Fill out and submit the RE Form 237 (click here) along with the fingerprinting fee. The Live Scan service provider will electronically transmit your fingerprints to the Department of Justice. Keep a copy of the form and receipt for your records.

Pay the Fee: Be prepared to pay the fingerprinting fee, which varies by provider. The fee typically includes the cost of the Live Scan service and the background check. Confirm the total cost when scheduling your appointment.

Background Check

The DRE will conduct a background check using your fingerprints. This check ensures you meet the honesty and integrity standards required for a real estate license. Any issues identified during the background check may need to be addressed before your license is granted.

If any issues arise during the background check, be prepared to provide additional documentation or explanations. Demonstrating honesty and taking responsibility for past actions can positively impact the DRE’s decision. Seek legal advice if necessary to navigate any complex issues.

Step 5: Submit the Salesperson License Application

The next step is to submit the Salesperson License Application. This application confirms that you have passed the exam and completed the fingerprinting requirement.

Application Process

  1. Complete the Form: Fill out the form available on the DRE website. Ensure all sections are completed accurately.
  2. Include Exam Results: Include proof that you passed the exam. This documentation is crucial for the DRE to verify your eligibility.
  3. Attach Live Scan Form: Attach your Live Scan Service form. This proof confirms that you have completed the fingerprinting requirement.
  4. Pay the Fee: As of 2023, the fee is $245. This fee must be submitted along with your application.

After submitting your application, you can track its status online through the DRE’s website. Regularly checking the status can help you stay informed about any updates or additional requirements.

Step 6: Find a Real Estate Broker to Sponsor You

Find a Sponsoring Broker

Once you pass the exam, you need to find a sponsoring broker to activate your license. Look for a brokerage that aligns with your goals and offers the support you need.

What to Look for in a Brokerage

Culture and Environment: Find a supportive and collaborative environment. The right culture can significantly impact your job satisfaction and success.

Commission Structure: Understand the financial arrangements. Different brokerages offer different commission splits, so choose one that suits your financial goals.

Training and Support: Choose a broker who provides ample training and mentorship opportunities. Early career support is crucial for your development and success.

Questions to Ask During Interviews

  • What training programs do you offer for new agents?
  • How does your commission split work, and are there any additional fees?
  • What kind of support and resources will I have access to?
  • Can you provide references from other agents in your brokerage?

For more interview preparation, check out our guide on 17 Brokerage Interview Questions.

Top Brokerages to Consider

Choosing the right broker is crucial as it impacts your early career significantly. Consider top-rated brokers like eXp Realty, Keller Williams, Coldwell Banker, and Compass.
metaDescription: Learn how to get a real estate license in California with our comprehensive guide. From pre-licensing courses to passing the exam, we cover it all.

content:
How to Get a Real Estate License – Learn the step-by-step process to obtain your real estate license, including state-specific requirements for Florida, Texas, California, and more, plus expert exam preparation tips.

Table of Contents

  1. Choosing the Right Real Estate School
  2. How to get a Real Estate License – Basic Requirements

In most states, you need to complete pre-licensing education covering essential topics like real estate principles, practices, and legal aspects.

Choosing the Right Real Estate School

  • Research and Reviews: Look for schools with high pass rates and positive feedback.
  • Online vs. In-Person: Choose based on your schedule and learning preferences.
  • Course Materials and Support: Ensure the school provides high-quality resources and instructor access.

Study Tips

  • Daily Study Schedule: Create a schedule for regular review sessions. (Asana provides a great FREE task manager)
  • Flashcards: Use flashcards for key terms and concepts.
  • Practice Tests: Regularly take practice tests to familiarize yourself with the exam format.
  • Complete the Application Form: Fill out the required form on your state’s real estate regulatory website.
  • Application Processing Time: Processing can take several weeks. Ensure your application is complete to avoid delays.
  • Tracking Your Application: Track your application status online and contact the regulatory body if there are delays.

The exam is typically a 3-hour test with multiple-choice questions. A minimum score of 70% is usually required to pass.

Preparation Tips

  • Review Course Materials: Revisit textbooks and notes from pre-license courses.
  • Practice Exams: Take practice exams to familiarize yourself with the format.
  • Study Groups: Join or form study groups for discussion and shared learning.
  • Exam Prep Courses: Enroll in prep courses for structured study and practice.

Exam Day Tips

  • Arrive Early: Avoid last-minute stress by arriving early.
  • Bring Required Identification: Ensure you have a valid photo ID.
  • Stay Calm and Focused: Manage your time wisely and stay composed.
  • Exam Room Etiquette: Follow all instructions and ask for help if needed.

After passing the exam, complete fingerprinting for a background check to meet honesty and integrity standards.

Steps to Get Fingerprinted

  1. Live Scan Service: Use an approved provider and schedule an appointment.
  2. Submit the Form: Follow service instructions.
  3. Pay Fees: Typically $15 to $80, varying by state.

Addressing Issues

  • Provide additional documentation if needed. Demonstrate honesty and responsibility.

Note

Most states require fingerprinting, but some do not. Check your state’s specific requirements.

Submit your application after passing the exam and completing fingerprinting, as required by your state.

Application Checklist

  1. Complete the Application Form: Fill out the necessary form from your state’s real estate regulatory website.
  2. Attach Exam Results: Include proof of passing the exam.
  3. Include Fingerprinting Proof: Submit your fingerprinting completion form, if required by your state.
  4. Pay the License Fee: Submit the required fee (amount varies by state).

After submission, track your application status online and address any additional requirements promptly.

Note

While the basic steps are similar, specific requirements and fees vary by state. Always refer to your state’s real estate regulatory body for precise instructions.

Next, you need a sponsoring broker to activate your license. Look for a brokerage that aligns with your goals and offers the support you need.

Considerations

  1. Brokerage Culture: Find a supportive and collaborative environment.
  2. Commission Splits: Understand how commission splits work and any additional fees.
  3. Training and Mentorship: Ensure there are programs for new agents and ongoing support.

Questions to Ask Potential Brokers

Top 17 Brokerage Interview Questions

  • What training programs do you offer for new agents?
  • How does your commission split work, and are there any additional fees?
  • What kind of support and resources will I have access to?
  • Can you provide references from other agents in your brokerage?

Top Brokerages to Consider

Choosing the right broker is crucial for your early career success.

These are ballparked numbers for you to generalize how much everything may cost. Hint: it’s not cheap to start out in real estate.

Starting a career in real estate across the U.S. involves several initial expenses and requires careful financial planning. Here’s a breakdown of typical costs and planning tips:

Starting Costs

1. Initial Expenses: Includes licensing fees, marketing expenses, office supplies, and technology tools. Typical costs might be:

  • Pre-Licensing Course: $99-$700
  • Exam Fee: $60 per attempt
  • Application Fee: $245
  • Fingerprinting Fee: Approximately $60
  • Marketing Materials: Costs for business cards, signage, and online advertising

2. Professional Memberships:

  • National Association of Realtors (NAR): Annual dues approximately $156, plus a $45 special assessment for the Consumer Advertising Campaign, totaling around $201.
  • State and Local Associations: Membership fees can vary. Typically, local Realtor association fees range from $200 to $300 annually.Multiple Listing Service (MLS): Fees can vary significantly by region. Generally, expect to pay anywhere from $300 to $500 annually.Supra Key Fees: Include an initial setup fee and a monthly or annual service fee, generally around $50 for setup and $20 to $25 per month for service.

Budgeting Tips

  • Create a Budget: Track expenses and forecast income, planning for slower months to maintain financial stability.
  • Emergency Fund: Set aside funds to cover unexpected costs or slow periods.

Income Management

  • Commission Structure: Real estate agents earn through sales commissions. Commission splits vary widely, typically from 50/50 to 80/20 or higher, depending on the brokerage.
  • Tax Planning: As an independent contractor, keep track of deductible expenses, make estimated tax payments, and maintain good records. Consult a tax professional to ensure compliance and optimize tax strategy.

These estimates are subject to change and can vary by location and specific circumstances. Always check local regulations and consult with local Realtor associations for the most accurate and up-to-date information.

How to get a Real Estate License – Basic Requirements

Generally, all states require a high school diploma or equivalent, U.S. citizenship, proof of state residency, and completion of state-approved pre-licensing courses. Additionally, many states mandate a background check and may require proof of errors and omissions insurance.

  1. Age: Most states require applicants to be at least 18 years old. Some states, like New York, require applicants to be at least 20 years old to become a broker.
  2. Education: A high school diploma or equivalent is typically required. Additionally, applicants must complete state-approved pre-licensing courses, which cover real estate principles, laws, and practices. The number of required hours varies by state, ranging from 40 to 180 hours.
  3. Residency: Applicants must be permanent residents of the state in which they are applying for the license.
  4. Background Check: Most states require a criminal background check to ensure the applicant has no disqualifying criminal history.
  5. Pre-Licensing Education: Completion of pre-licensing education is mandatory. The specific number of hours and the content of these courses depend on state regulations. For example, New York requires 77 hours of coursework for agents and 152 hours for brokers.
  6. Examination: Applicants must pass a state licensing exam that tests their knowledge of real estate laws, practices, and principles. The exam typically includes both national and state-specific sections.
  7. Sponsorship: In some states, like New York, applicants must be sponsored by a licensed real estate broker to activate their license.

Additional Considerations

  • License Reciprocity: Some states have reciprocity agreements with other states, which can simplify the licensing process for those already licensed elsewhere. This may allow applicants to skip certain pre-licensing requirements but still necessitates passing state-specific portions of the exam.
  • Continuing Education: After obtaining a license, most states require real estate professionals to complete continuing education courses to maintain their license and stay updated on industry changes.

On average, it takes about 4-6 months to get a real estate license through traditional classroom courses. However, if you take online real estate pre-licensing courses, you can potentially complete the process more quickly:

  • Online courses can be completed in as little as 8 weeks, depending on how quickly you pace yourself.
  • In California specifically, the quickest you can get your real estate license is approximately 14.5 weeks (about 3.5 months).
  • Some online schools report that students can complete the process in 2-5 months on average.

Key Factors Affecting the Timeline:

  1. State requirements for pre-licensing education hours: For example, California requires 135 hours.
  2. Whether you take online or classroom courses: Online is generally faster.
  3. How much time you can dedicate to studying: Self-paced online courses allow for flexibility.
  4. The exam application and scheduling process: This can take 6-8 weeks in some states.
  5. Time needed to study for and pass the licensing exam: Preparation time varies by individual.

Fastest Possible Timeline Breakdown:

  • Pre-licensing education: 7.5 weeks minimum (for online courses in California).
  • Exam application processing: 6-8 weeks.
  • Exam scheduling and taking: 1-2 weeks.

Keep in mind that while it’s possible to complete the process quickly, taking more time to thoroughly learn the material can be beneficial for passing the exam and starting your career.

  • The exam is considered challenging and requires thorough preparation. It tests knowledge of real estate principles, laws, and practices, and a significant portion of the exam focuses on vocabulary and key concepts.
  1. Pass rates vary by state, typically ranging from 50% to 70% for first-time test takers.
  2. The exam covers a wide range of topics, including property ownership, land use regulations, financing, and real estate calculations.
  3. Most states have a time limit of 2-4 hours for the exam, which can add pressure.
  4. The exam usually consists of 100-150 multiple-choice questions, testing both national and state-specific real estate knowledge.
  5. Many test-takers find the math questions and state-specific laws to be the most challenging aspects.
  6. Successful candidates typically dedicate 2-4 weeks of focused study time before the exam.

While the exam is designed to be comprehensive and challenging, it’s important to remember that with thorough preparation and study, most candidates can pass successfully.

The real estate exam typically covers a variety of topics essential for understanding real estate practices and laws. Key areas of focus include:

  1. Real Estate Principles: Fundamental concepts and terminology related to real estate transactions, ownership, and property rights.
  2. Real Estate Practices: Practical applications of real estate principles, including the processes involved in buying, selling, and leasing properties.
  3. Property Ownership: Different types of property ownership, including freehold and leasehold estates, and the rights associated with each.
  4. Land Use Regulations: Understanding zoning laws, land use planning, and environmental regulations that affect property development and use.
  5. Financing: Knowledge of various financing options available for real estate transactions, including mortgages, loans, and the role of financial institutions.
  6. Real Estate Calculations: Mathematical concepts related to property valuation, commissions, and financing, which are often tested in the exam.
  7. State-Specific Laws: Each state has its own set of laws and regulations governing real estate transactions, which candidates must understand to pass the exam.
  8. Ethics and Professional Conduct: Understanding the ethical responsibilities of real estate professionals and the importance of maintaining integrity in transactions.

Candidates are advised to review both national and state-specific materials to ensure comprehensive preparation for the exam.

The duration of the real estate exam varies by state, but generally falls within the following parameters:

  1. Most real estate licensing exams last between 1.5 to 3.5 hours.
  2. The exam is typically divided into two parts: a national portion and a state-specific portion.
  3. In California, for example, the salesperson exam consists of 150 multiple-choice questions with a time limit of 3 hours and 15 minutes.
  4. The broker exam in California is more extensive, with 200 questions and a time limit of 5 hours.
  5. Some states, like New York, allow up to 1.5 hours for the salesperson exam and 2.5 hours for the broker exam.
  6. The number of questions can range from 100 to 150 for most states, influencing the overall exam duration.

It’s important to note that the exact length can vary, and candidates should check with their state’s real estate commission or licensing board for the most accurate and up-to-date information.

The number of questions you can miss and still pass the real estate exam varies by state, but generally:

  1. Most states require a passing score of 70-75%, meaning you can miss 25-30% of the questions and still pass.
  2. In California, for example, the salesperson exam consists of 150 multiple-choice questions, and you need to answer at least 105 questions correctly (70%) to pass.
  3. For the California broker exam, which has 200 questions, you need to answer at least 150 correctly (75%) to pass.
  4. In New York, the passing score is 70% for both the salesperson and broker exams.
  5. Some states, like Florida, require a higher passing score of 75%, allowing fewer missed questions.
  6. The exact number of questions you can miss depends on the total number of questions on your state’s exam, which can range from 100 to 200.

It’s important to note that while you can afford to miss some questions, aiming for a higher score is always beneficial. This ensures you have a buffer in case you encounter particularly challenging questions.

If you fail the real estate exam, the process for retaking it varies by state, but generally includes the following steps:

  1. Retake Eligibility: Most states allow candidates to retake the exam after failing. However, there may be a waiting period before you can attempt it again, typically ranging from a few days to a few weeks.
  2. Exam Fees: You will likely need to pay a retake fee each time you attempt the exam. This fee can vary depending on the state and the testing provider.
  3. Preparation: It is advisable to review your study materials and identify areas where you struggled before retaking the exam. Many candidates find it helpful to take additional practice exams or enroll in a prep course to improve their chances of passing on the next attempt.
  4. State-Specific Rules: Each state has its own rules regarding how many times you can retake the exam and any additional requirements that may apply. For example, some states may require you to complete additional coursework if you fail multiple times.
  5. Passing Score: Remember that the passing score typically ranges from 70% to 75%, so understanding the exam format and content is crucial for success.
  6. Time Limit: After passing the exam, you usually have a limited time frame (often six months) to apply for your real estate license. Failing to do so may require you to retake the exam again.

Overall, while failing the exam can be discouraging, many candidates successfully pass on their subsequent attempts with proper preparation and study.

It is exclusively focused on real estate education, offering courses for every step of a real estate career, from pre-licensing to continuing education and career advancement. The courses are state-approved and designed to be accessible from any device, providing students with the flexibility to study anywhere.

Overview:

AceableAgent offers three pre-licensing packages, all of which include the required coursework. The courses are fully online and accessible via desktop, laptop, tablet, or smartphone. This accessibility is one of AceableAgent’s standout features, allowing students to study on the go. Courses are developed by experienced professionals and are accredited by ARELLO. Additionally, AceableAgent is known for its interactive coursework, which helps students grasp and retain information effectively.

Why AceableAgent is Great for Pre-Licensing:

AceableAgent’s pre-licensing courses are available in multiple states, ensuring they meet state-specific requirements. The courses include engaging video lectures, interactive content, and practice exams to help students prepare effectively for their licensing exams. AceableAgent offers a satisfaction guarantee and provides career resources to help new agents start their careers successfully.

User Experiences and Feedback:

Students have reported that AceableAgent’s courses are particularly user-friendly, with a modern interface that makes navigation easy. The mobile app is highly rated for its convenience, allowing users to study during commutes or breaks. The interactive content, including quizzes and video explanations, has been praised for making complex topics easier to understand. Additionally, AceableAgent’s customer service, though sometimes slow, is generally helpful and responsive to student needs.

To view their current pricing for pre-licensing, first click this linked button, then under “Choose Your State to Learn More” click on the drop down menu to select your state. If it is not listed, click on browse all at the bottom of the drop down menu.

The CE Shop

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Course is easy to follow, high pass rates among students

Why We Chose It: The CE Shop offers a variety of real estate education options with an interactive and inquiry-based approach in their studying methods. While their focus is mainly on continuing education, they also provide excellent pre-licensing courses, exam prep, and post-licensing education. Their courses are accredited by ARELLO and have received numerous awards for their educational programs.

Overview: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses can be taken in 34 states, through four different course packages: Courses Only, Standard Package, Value Package, and Premium Package. Every package comes with business ebooks, career resources, downloadable resources, real estate glossary, digital flashcards, study schedules, and access to instructor-led webinars. Students have praised the course content for being easy to follow and highly informative, which has led to high pass rates.

Why The CE Shop is Great for Pre-Licensing: The CE Shop’s pre-licensing courses emphasize real-world applications with scenario-based learning. This approach helps students apply their knowledge to practical situations they will face in their real estate careers. Additionally, The CE Shop provides an exam prep edge program that offers additional practice tests and study aids to ensure students are well-prepared for their licensing exams.

User Experiences and Feedback: The CE Shop is well-regarded for its robust customer support and comprehensive resources. The ability to access instructor-led webinars provides an additional layer of support and interaction, which can be particularly beneficial for students who need more guidance. The frequent promotions and discounts make it a cost-effective option for many. Students appreciate the clear and structured study schedules, which help them stay on track and complete the course efficiently.

Colibri Real Estate

SmartAgentAlliance Score: A
Top Feature: Affordable and comprehensive study materials

Why We Chose It: Colibri Real Estate is known for its affordability and thorough course materials. It provides excellent support to students preparing for their exams and offers a range of courses that cater to different learning needs. Colibri courses are designed to be clear and easy to understand, making them a great choice for budget-conscious students.

Overview: Colibri Real Estate offers various online courses with comprehensive study materials. The courses are designed to prepare students effectively for their licensing exams, with detailed support and resources. The pricing is competitive, making it an accessible option for many students.

Why Colibri Real Estate is Great for Pre-Licensing: Colibri Real Estates’ pre-licensing courses include interactive study tools such as flashcards, practice tests, and exam simulators. The courses are state-approved and designed to meet all the requirements for licensure. Colibri also offers a “pass or don’t pay” guarantee, ensuring students can retake the course if they don’t pass the exam on the first try. They also provide a career starter guide to help new agents transition smoothly into their real estate careers.

User Experiences and Feedback: Colibri Real Estate has a strong reputation for providing value for money. The comprehensive study materials are frequently updated to reflect the latest industry standards and practices. Students have noted that the detailed exam preparation support, including practice exams and study guides, is particularly helpful for passing the state licensing exams. The school’s customer support, though sometimes slow, is knowledgeable and helpful in resolving issues.

Our Review Process:

At SmartAgentAlliance, our goal is to provide accurate and helpful reviews of online real estate schools to assist prospective real estate agents in making informed decisions. Our review process involves several key steps:

Research and Data Collection:

We begin by gathering comprehensive information about each real estate school, including course offerings, pricing, accreditation, and user reviews. This involves visiting the schools’ websites, reading third-party reviews, and gathering feedback from current and former students.

Evaluation Criteria:

Our evaluation is based on several important criteria, including:

  • Course Quality: We assess the content and structure of the courses to ensure they cover all necessary topics comprehensively and are easy to follow.
  • Accessibility: We evaluate the flexibility and accessibility of the courses, including the availability of mobile apps and study materials.
  • Pass Rates: We consider the pass rates of students who have completed the courses and taken the licensing exam.
  • Student Support: We look at the level of support provided to students, including access to instructors, customer service, and additional resources like study guides and practice exams.
  • Pricing: We compare the cost of the courses relative to the value they offer, including any discounts or payment plans available.
  • User Feedback: We gather and analyze feedback from students who have taken the courses to get an understanding of their experiences and satisfaction levels.

Scoring and Ranking:

Each school is scored based on the evaluation criteria, and an overall score is calculated. The scores are then used to rank the schools, with additional considerations given to standout features that may set a school apart from the rest.

A pre-licensing course is a state-required educational program that prospective real estate agents must complete before they can take the real estate licensing exam. These courses cover fundamental topics in real estate, including property laws, real estate practices, and ethics.

The duration varies depending on the state requirements and the pace at which the student completes the coursework. Generally, it can take anywhere from a few weeks to several months.

Yes, the schools reviewed here are accredited by relevant real estate regulatory bodies such as ARELLO and state real estate commissions, ensuring the courses meet state requirements for licensure.

Support varies by school but generally includes access to instructors via email or chat, customer service support, and sometimes live webinars or Q&A sessions.

The Wolf Pack team at eXp Realty offers expert-led courses like Social Agent Academy 3.0, the Wolf Pack Hub, and the Investor Army for property flipping.
